awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evaluation of ACA Reform
awd_abstract_narration:
At the core of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) is the "individual mandate" law. Under this law, each individual in the ACA's "health insurance exchanges" needs to buy coverage or pay a penalty. Individual mandate has perhaps been the most controversial part of the ACA. This research aims at answering two crucial questions about this law. First, by how much would the uninsurance rate increase after lifting individual mandate? Second, to what extent could the proposed replacements to this law mitigate the negative impact of that lift on coverage?

This research develops an economic model of healthcare exchanges that incorporates asymmetric information and consumer dynamics. It allows for heterogeneity in health statuses of individuals, enabling it to capture adverse selection -- the main reason why the market could collapse without individual mandate. The model is dynamic, allowing it to capture consumers' foresighted decision making. This is crucial for evaluating the impact of the proposed replacements to individual mandate, which all penalize consumers who stay uninsured today with restricted access to health insurance in the future. Using the model, the investigators examine how different ways to replace or reform the ACA might affect the performance of the health insurance exchange and the consumer welfare.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is aimed at evaluating the performances of different potential policies designed to encourage health insurance exchange participation. Currently, our work is still in progress. We have developed a large model of health insurance participation. We have a working calibration of the model to data from the Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF) which is not our final calibration; and this is the reason why we have not yet submitted our results for publication or circulated them braodly.

 

From conducting simulation analysis using our current calibration, we reach the following preliminary qualitative results:

 

1. Even though the extant economics literature suggests that pre-existing-condition pricing is substantially more harmful to social welfare compared to adverse selection, the wedge between the two may be diminished or even reversed when insurance is heavily subsidiezed. This is because subsidies on insurance premiums effectively acts as an insurance against pre-existing conditions.

 

2. To the extent that the pure act of boosting participation (as opposed to social welfare) would matter to policymakers, the most effective policy is an ACA style individual mandate with larger penalty than what is currently imposed. Policies that aim at punishing non-participation by blocking or restricting future access to insurance are predicted to be less effective.

 

Note that these results are preliminary, due in part to the fact that our model calibration is not finalized. We are now in the process of calibrating it to data from the American Consumer Survey (ACS) in addition to the Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF). Once the calibration procedure is complete, the model will be ready for policy recommendation.
